unnormalised: Okay, so someone asked about the best airline for domestic travel in India. It really depends on what you're looking for, right? Like, are you prioritizing cost, comfort, or on-time performance? There's no single "best" answer, but I can give you my two cents from my experience.
normalised: Okay, so someone asked about the best airline for domestic travel in India. It really depends on what you are looking for, right? Like, are you prioritizing cost, comfort, or on-time performance? There is no single "best" answer, but I can give you my two cents from my experience.

unnormalised: For budget travelers, IndiGo is often the go-to. They usually have the cheapest fares, especially if you book well in advance. I once got a ticket from Delhi to Bangalore for just Rs. 3500 booking 2 months prior! Just be aware that they charge extra for everything – meals, seat selection, even checking in a bag beyond the carry-on limit. Also, sometimes their customer service can be a bit slow, so keep that in mind.
normalised: For budget travelers, IndiGo is often the go-to. They usually have the cheapest fares, especially if you book well in advance. I once got a ticket from Delhi to Bangalore for just rupee three thousand five hundred booking two months prior! Just be aware that they charge extra for everything – meals, seat selection, even checking in a bag beyond the carry-on limit. Also, sometimes their customer service can be a bit slow, so keep that in mind.

unnormalised: SpiceJet is another budget option, and I've found their legroom to be slightly better than IndiGo on some flights. Their deals are pretty good sometimes. I flew from Mumbai to Goa for around ₹4000 during the off-season, which was a steal. They've had some financial troubles in the past, which sometimes affects their on-time performance, so it's worth checking recent reviews before booking.

unnormalised: If you're looking for a bit more comfort, Air India might be a better choice. They often have more spacious seating and complimentary meals on board. Plus, they have a wider network, including smaller towns and cities. I remember flying Air India from Kolkata to Guwahati and it was a surprisingly pleasant experience. Although they’ve had their share of issues in the past, they're trying to improve their service under the Tata Group.

unnormalised: Vistara is another option for premium travel. They offer a more luxurious experience, with comfortable seats, better food, and generally better service. The price will definetly be higher compared to other options. They’re known for their consistent on-time performance as well.

unnormalised: Then there are airlines like Akasa Air, which is relatively new to the scene, and aims for that sweet spot between budget and premium. I have flown with them only once, from Chennai to Ahmedabad and it was decent.

unnormalised: Ultimately, the best airline for you will depend on your individual needs and preferences. I always check multiple websites like MakeMyTrip, Yatra, and the airline's own website before booking to compare prices and flight times. Don't forget to factor in things like baggage allowance and cancellation policies too! Happy travels bhai!
